Homework (due 0401)

Complete these for Monday, April 1. Show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Graph the following ellipses. Identify all six pieces of key information for each.

    1. \(\frac{x^2}{9}+\frac{y^2}{16}=1\)

      This equation has the standard form for an ellipse. Since the larger denominator is that of the \(y\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is vertical. We see that \(a=4\) and \(b=3,\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{4^2-3^2}=\sqrt{7}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    2. \(\frac{x^2}{16}+\frac{y^2}{9}=1\)

      This equation has the standard form for an ellipse. Since the larger denominator is that of the \(x\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is horizontal. We see that \(a=4\) and \(b=3,\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{4^2-3^2}=\sqrt{7}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    3. \(\frac{x^2}{5}+\frac{y^2}{7}=1\)

      This equation has the standard form for an ellipse. Since the larger denominator is that of the \(y\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is vertical. We see that \(a=\sqrt{7}\) and \(b=\sqrt{5},\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{7-5}=\sqrt{2}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    4. \(9x^2+16y^2-144=0\)

      This equation is not in standard form. We can put it in standard form as follows: \(9x^2+16y^2-144=0\Rightarrow 9x^2+16y^2=144\Rightarrow \frac{9x^2}{144}+\frac{16y^2}{144}=1\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{16}+\frac{y^2}{9}=1.\) This is the same equation as problem 1b. The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    5. \(25x^2+9y^2-225=0\)

      This equation is not in standard form. We can put it in standard form as follows: \(25x^2+9y^2-225=0\Rightarrow 25x^2+9y^2=225\Rightarrow \frac{25x^2}{225}+\frac{9y^2}{225}=1\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{9}+\frac{y^2}{25}=1.\) Since the larger denominator is that of the \(y\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is vertical. We see that \(a=4\) and \(b=3,\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{4^2-3^2}=\sqrt{7}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    6. \(x^2+4y^2-4=0\)

      This equation is not in standard form. We can put it in standard form as follows: \(x^2+4y^2-4=0\Rightarrow x^2+4y^2=4\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{4}+\frac{4y^2}{4}=1\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{4}+\frac{y^2}{1}=1.\) Since the larger denominator is that of the \(x\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is horizontal. We see that \(a=2\) and \(b=1,\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{2^2-1^2}=\sqrt{3}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    7. \(\frac{x^2}{3}+2y^2-6=0\)

      This equation is not in standard form. We can put it in standard form as follows: \(\frac{x^2}{3}+2y^2-6=0\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{3}+2y^2=6\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{18}+\frac{2y^2}{6}=1\Rightarrow \frac{x^2}{18}+\frac{y^2}{3}=1.\) Since the larger denominator is that of the \(x\)-term, this is an ellipse whose major axis is horizontal. We see that \(a=\sqrt{18}\) and \(b=\sqrt{3},\) and we can calculate that \(c=\sqrt{18-3}=\sqrt{15}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

  2. Graph the following parabolas. Identify the focus, vertex, directrix, and axis of symmetry for each.

    1. \(x^2=4y\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens upward. In this equation, \(4c=4,\) and so \(c=1.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    2. \(x^2=8y\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens upward. In this equation, \(4c=8,\) and so \(c=2.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    3. \(x^2=3y\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens upward. In this equation, \(4c=3,\) and so \(c=\frac{3}{4}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    4. \(x^2=-12y\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens downward. In this equation, \(4c=12,\) and so \(c=3.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    5. \(y^2=2x\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens rightward. In this equation, \(4c=2,\) and so \(c=\frac{1}{2}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:

    6. \(y^2=-5x\)

      This equation has the standard form for a parabola that opens leftward. In this equation, \(4c=5,\) and so \(c=\frac{5}{4}.\) The key information is labeled on the following graph:
